===Ethics in health care===
 
===Ethics in health care===
  +
{{seemain2|bioethics|medical ethics}}
     
One of the major areas where ethicists practice is in the field of [[health care]]. This includes [[medicine]], [[nursing]], [[pharmacy]] and allied health professions. Example issues are [[euthanasia]], [[abortion]], medical experiments, [[vaccine trials]], truth telling, patient rights and autonomy, rationing of health care (such as [[triage]]).
 
One of the major areas where ethicists practice is in the field of [[health care]]. This includes [[medicine]], [[nursing]], [[pharmacy]] and allied health professions. Example issues are [[euthanasia]], [[abortion]], medical experiments, [[vaccine trials]], truth telling, patient rights and autonomy, rationing of health care (such as [[triage]]).
−
''See also [[bioethics]], [[medical ethics]]''

===Ethics in psychology===
+
====Ethics in psychology====
     
By the [[1960s]] there was increased interest in [[moral reasoning]]. [[Psychology|Psychologists]] such as [[Lawrence Kohlberg]] and [[Carol Gilligan]] developed theories which are based on the idea that moral behaviour is made possible by moral reasoning. Their theories subdivided moral reasoning into so-called stages, which refer to the set of principles or methods that a person uses for ethical judgement. The first and most famous theory of this type was [[Kohlberg's stages of moral development|Kohlberg's theory of moral development.]].
 
By the [[1960s]] there was increased interest in [[moral reasoning]]. [[Psychology|Psychologists]] such as [[Lawrence Kohlberg]] and [[Carol Gilligan]] developed theories which are based on the idea that moral behaviour is made possible by moral reasoning. Their theories subdivided moral reasoning into so-called stages, which refer to the set of principles or methods that a person uses for ethical judgement. The first and most famous theory of this type was [[Kohlberg's stages of moral development|Kohlberg's theory of moral development.]].
